creditline: Gift of Louis W. Hill, Jr.
inscription: explanation and tradition regarding white lilies
medium: Woodblock print (nishiki-e); ink and color on paper
portfolio: From Collection of Flowers Representing the Gods of Good Fortune (Hana zukushi mitate fukurokuju 花盡見立福禄壽)
text: Although birds and flowers are not a common subject for fan prints, Hiroshige created a number of fan series with floral designs between the 1840s and 1850s. This is one from a three-print set that features flowers symbolic of good fortune. In addition to their obvious beauty, spotted lilies with their edible roots have long been a source of nutrition in Japan. Thus, they represent an alternative meaning of the ideograph for prosperity (roku), which can connote "gift."
title: Roku, Spotted Lilies
